11.text:
>> Simon Blackburn: Most bills start in the
House of Commons. When they’ve finished

14.text:
with a bill, and it’s been through all its
stages there, a hard copy is still walked

19.text:
up to the House of Lords, wrapped up in ribbon.
It gets brought into the chamber and a government

26.text:
minister will stand up and read the long title.
This is known as the first reading.

30.text:
The long title is a paragraph in the bill which just
sums up what that bill is doing.

36.text:
Then the hard copy of the bill gets taken out of the
chamber and up to our office where we keep it safe.

42.text: Second reading is a debate and Members take

45.text:
it in turns to stand up and talk about the
subject. It’s quite useful because they

50.text:
can also take the opportunity to tell the
government: ‘well, this is what I think

54.text:
of your bill. These are the bits I’m going
to try and change later on.’

59.text:
Once we’ve received the bill, and once it’s
had its second reading, then a bill is open

63.text:
for amendments. Members come into the legislation
office and discuss with us the changes they’d

69.text:
like to make to the bill. Then we put everything
in the right order and print it up, ready

74.text:
for everyone to look at, when it’s in the
chamber.

77.text:
If, at second reading, lots of people disagree
with the subject then they can have a vote

83.text:
and they can decide to throw out the whole
bill there and then.

87.text: But that doesn’t tend to happen very often.

89.text: >> Member of the House of Lords: My Lords,

90.text:
I beg to move that the House do now resolve
itself into a committee upon the bill.

94.text:
>> Simon Blackburn: Committee stage – everybody
turns up and they go through the bill line

98.text:
by line. Most of the amendments are a chance
to try and work out what the government’s

103.text:
thinking, what it’s policy is in an area.
People suggest changes just to see what the

107.text:
government says about them and whether they’ll
accept them or not.

111.text:
>> Member of the House of Lords: Questions:
one is what is the urgency to consider the

114.text:
report stage?
>> Simon Blackburn: So the next stage is called

117.text:
report stage. This time they go through the
bill line by line again but the amendments

123.text:
are right down to the nitty gritty. These
are changes that people really want to make.

130.text:
Quite often we get more votes at report stage
because people really want to push the government

134.text:
and find out how many people agree with them.
>> Lord Speaker: ‘Not contents’, 218.

139.text:
Therefore the ‘not contents’ have it.
>> Simon Blackburn: The very last stage is

142.text:
called third reading and this is pretty much
a tidying up, if there’s been a big change

147.text:
earlier on which has lots of consequential
little changes.

150.text:
After third reading, all the changes that
have been made will be stuck in or crossed

157.text:
out, as the case may be. Then it’s wrapped
up in red ribbon with a message saying: ‘Dear

162.text:
House of Commons, here is a bill that the
House of Lords have passed. Please will you

166.text:
consider it?’
>> Messenger: Message from the Lords.

169.text:
>> Simon Blackburn: Ping pong is the point
where a bill is going backwards and forwards

174.text:
between the two Houses. All they’re looking
at are the areas where they can’t agree,

179.text:
so everything else that’s agreed is put
to one side. On the areas where they can’t

182.text:
agree, they try and find a compromise. The
House of Lords might say: ‘we don’t like

186.text:
this but what do you think of this instead?’
And the Commons will either say ‘yes’

189.text:
or they might say ‘no, we don’t agree
with that policy but how about this compromise?’

193.text:
They’ll whittle it down until everybody’s
agreed on a way forward.

198.text:
When both Houses have finished the bill then
the Queen is asked to signify that she’s

203.text:
happy with it. When that happens, in both
Houses the Speaker and the Lord Speaker stand

209.text:
up and announce that the bill has been given
its Royal Assent.

212.text:
>> Lord Speaker: My Lords I have to notify
the House, in accordance with the Royal Assent

216.text:
Act of 1967, that the Queen has signified
her Royal Assent to the following Acts.

221.text:
>> Simon Blackburn: Then the bill goes off
and the final copy is printed. It’s this

225.text:
copy that is taken up to the Parliamentary
Archives and it’s the official record.
